key_points: President Joe Biden announced new federal vaccine mandates affecting up to 100 million Americans to combat the COVID-19 delta variant.
The mandates apply to private-sector employees, health care workers, federal contractors, and others.
Biden criticized unvaccinated Americans, stating their refusal to get vaccinated has cost all Americans.
Republican leaders and some union chiefs accused Biden of overstepping his authority and violating constitutional rights.
The American Medical Association, the National Association of Manufacturers, and the Business Roundtable expressed support for Biden's efforts to increase vaccination rates.
New rules require employers with more than 100 workers to mandate vaccines or weekly testing, affecting about 80 million Americans.
Employees of the executive branch and contractors with the federal government must be vaccinated, with no testing option, affecting several million more workers.
Biden's address also included efforts to increase virus testing, support for safe school operations, and urging large venues to require vaccinations or negative tests for entry.
The new requirements will be enforced through various federal agencies, with specific penalties and guidelines for non-compliance.
Despite a high vaccination rate, the U.S. is experiencing a significant increase in COVID-19 infections, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to last year.
spokespersons: Gov. Henry McMaster (Governor of South Carolina)
Everett Kelley (National President, American Federation of Government Employees)
